basics.intro: Keep Your Personal Information Private Online. Sharing too much personal information online can seriously compromise your privacy. Companies and hackers can use your details for profiling, tracking, identity theft, and other harmful activities without your consent. Protecting your privacy should be a top concern for all of your online activities.
tips: Only provide necessary personal details online when required
Use nicknames or pseudonyms instead of real names when possible
Check app/website privacy policies before using
Adjust social media privacy settings to limit sharing
Provide fake or limited info if asked for unnecessary details
keyTakeaways: Think carefully before posting any personal details publicly online
Only share necessary info and use pseudonyms/nicknames where possible
Check how websites/apps will use your data before providing it

passwords.intro: Weak passwords leave your accounts and devices vulnerable to hacking. Follow these tips to create secure passwords that will keep your information protected.
tips: Use 12-14 characters, mixing upper/lowercase letters, numbers, and symbols. The longer the better.
Avoid common words, names, dates, or any personal info. These are easy to guess.
Don't use the same password for multiple accounts. If one is breached, they all will be.
Consider using a password manager app to generate and store unique passwords.
Change passwords every 90 days, especially for financial accounts or work devices.
Never share passwords over email, chat, or phone. Legitimate services will not ask for them.
On devices, use strong PIN codes, fingerprints, or facial recognition for logins when possible.
keyTakeaways: Use 12-14 characters mixing letters, numbers, and symbols
Never base on personal info or reuse passwords
Use a password manager to stay organized
Change passwords frequently, especially for sensitive accounts

websites.intro: With online threats like hacking, fraud, and identity theft on the rise, it's critically important to verify that a website is secure before entering any sensitive information like your login credentials, financial details, or personal data. Unfortunately, it can be tricky for everyday internet users to recognize signs of a legitimate, encrypted website. There are a few key indicators you need to check for - like 'https' URLs, padlock icons, and SSL certificates - to determine if a site is authentic and your connection to it is private. Taking just a quick moment to validate these security signals can protect you from cybercriminals and prevent your information from being intercepted or stolen as it's transmitted online. Don't let unfamiliar technical terms intimidate you - this tutorial will break down step-by-step what to look for so you can identify secure sites and browse the web safely.
tips: Check that the URL begins with 'https://' not just 'http://.' The 's' means it's secure.
Look for a padlock icon next to the URL bar. This also indicates the site uses encryption.
Click the padlock and verify the site has a valid, trusted SSL certificate.
Avoid sites with certificate warnings or expiration dates in the past.
Be wary of misspellings or substitutes in the URL (like using 'zero' instead of 'o').
Never ignore browser warnings about invalid certificates or not secure connections.
keyTakeaways: Only enter sensitive data on 'https://' websites
Verify padlock icons and valid SSL certificates
Heed all browser warnings about invalid sites
Avoid sites with misspellings or typos

phising.intro: Phishing is one of the most common and dangerous cyber threats facing internet users today. These sophisticated scams use social engineering techniques to fool victims into handing over sensitive information and can result in identity theft, financial fraud, and compromised accounts. It is critical that you be able to recognize the hallmark signals of a phishing attempt so you can avoid being duped. Criminals have gotten extremely skilled at creating authentic looking messages, websites, and communications that users unfortunately fall for. A little awareness and vigilance goes a long way in protecting yourself. This tutorial will cover the variety of ways phishing can occur over email, text, social media, and websites. I'll also provide key indicators to watch for and steps you can take to vet legitimacy before responding or clicking on anything suspicious. Don't let scammers catch you off guard - you can outsmart them by learning their tricks.
tips: Watch for suspicious links sent via email, text or social media messages. Don't click on them.
Check for poor spelling/grammar, threats, false urgency or requests for sensitive information.
Verify the sender's email address or account name. Scammers often spoof legitimate businesses.
Inspect URLs carefully. Fake sites use similar spellings or substitutes.
Call companies directly using official numbers to check if requests are valid.
Check for lack of HTTPS, padlock icons, and valid site certificates before entering info.
keyTakeaways: Watch for urgent requests for private details
Check sites for HTTPS, padlocks, certificates

antivirus.intro4: Viruses, malware, spyware, ransomware - the online world is filled with insidious threats aiming to infect your devices and compromise your security. The consequences can be devastating, from identity theft to wiped systems. That's why protecting your devices with a trusted antivirus is one of the most fundamental cybersecurity measures everyone should take.But with so many options out there, how do you select effective antivirus software? This tutorial will cover the key features to look for and best practices to ensure your antivirus is proactively defending across devices. Don't leave the door open for cybercriminals - a robust antivirus acts as an indispensable shield against digital infections.
tips4: Choose software from well-known cybersecurity vendors like Norton, McAfee, AVG, Avast, etc.
Ensure real-time scanning and active monitoring of all device activity.
Check that it scans downloads, networks, email attachments, and web traffic.
Select products offering extra features like firewalls, VPNs, or password managers.
Opt for software with artificial intelligence and heuristics to detect new threats.
Make sure all your devices are covered - PCs, phones, tablets, networks.
keyTakeaways4: Ensure real-time scanning across all devices
Utilize extra security tools like VPNs
